Award.AwardTitle: Flexible Core/Shell Nanocable - Carbon Microfiber Hybrid Composite Electrodes for High-Performance Supercapacitors

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding for synthesizing large quantities of conductive-core/transition-metal-oxide-shell nanocables on a highly flexible and strong carbon microfiber substrate. The primary goal of this work is to solve the three most critical limitations in supercapacitors for portable electronic devices and wearable electronics, i.e., inflexibility, low specific capacitance, and electrode failure resulting from ion insertion/extraction during charge/discharge cycling. The electrical conductive-cores will be used to support redox active transition-metal-oxide-shells with highly electrolytic accessible surface area and also to provide reliable electrical connections to the shells, enabling full utilization of transitional-metal-oxide and fast electronic and ionic conduction through the electrode. The carbon microfibers will offer not only flexibility and mechanical strength to the electrode but also more surface area than a flat conductive substrate for growing more nanocables, which further improves the specific capacitance and energy density. This research program will study the formation mechanisms of the core/shell nanocables grown on flexible carbon microfibers and the electrochemical energy storage mechanisms of the core/shell ? carbon microfiber hybrid composite electrodes. High throughput manufacturing of such composite electrodes with high flexibility, high specific capacitance, high energy density, high power density, fast charging/discharging rate, and long cycle life will be explored through the novel hierarchical nano/micro architecture design.

If successful, the results of this research will contribute to a better understanding of the manufacturing-structure-property-function of the core/shell ? carbon microfiber hybrid composites and their electrodes. This research has the potential to change the conventional concepts for flexible electrode design and to significantly impact existing electrode manufacturing technologies. The research advances made through this project will generate new knowledge that will be introduced to undergraduate and graduate students through existing courses and the research activities will be used as an educational platform for students at all levels to learn about nanomanufacturing and nanotechnology-enabled energy storage systems.

Institution.Name: University of Virginia Main Campus
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RECTOR & VISITORS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF VIRGINIA

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aims at synthesizing large quantities of conductive-core/transition-metal-oxide-shell nanocables on a highly flexible and strong carbon microfiber substrate. The primary goal of this work is to solve the three most critical limitations in supercapacitors for portable electronic devices and wearable electronics, i.e., inflexibility, low specific capacitance, and electrode failure resulting from ion insertion/extraction during charge/discharge cycling. The novelty of the approach is the use of electrical conductive-cores to support redox active transition-metal-oxide-shells to achieve highly electrolytic accessible surface area and reliable electrical connections to the shells, enabling full utilization of transitional-metal-oxide and fast electronic and ionic conduction through the electrode. This research program has studied the formation mechanisms of the core/shell nanocables grown on flexible carbon microfibers and the electrochemical energy storage mechanisms of the core/shell – carbon microfiber hybrid composite electrodes. High throughput manufacturing of such composite electrodes with high flexibility, high specific capacitance, high energy density, high power density, fast charging/discharging rate, and long cycle life has been achieved through the novel hierarchical nano/micro architecture design and roll-to-roll processes. Importantly, the flexible supercapacitors have been successfully assembled with flexible solar cells to realize self-sustaining power packs.  

The results of this research have contributed to a better understanding of the manufacturing-structure-property-function of the core/shell – carbon microfiber hybrid composites and their electrodes. This research has changed the conventional concepts for flexible electrode design and significantly impacted the electrode manufacturing technologies.

This project has enhanced the expertise of faculty in this area, helped recruit qualified students, developed new educational opportunities, and increased the public awareness of NSF- driven research and educational activities in NanoManufacturing. Through this project, the principal investigator and students have established collaboration opportunities with 4 universities and 1 national laboratory.  

This project supported 5 students (1 female student), resulted in 14 scientific papers in prestigious peer reviewed journals, 2 keynotes, 16 invited talks and 4 presentations at international conferences/workshops, and 1 US patent. The research activities were used as an educational platform for students at all levels to learn about NanoManufacturing. The research advances made through this project have generated new knowledge that has been introduced to undergraduate and graduate students through existing courses and newly developed courses (for instance, “Manufacturing Processes”, “Manufacturing and Process Technology”, “Micro/Nano Manufacturing”, “Nanomaterials”, and “Nano in a Global Context” offered/co-offered by the principal investigator). Students in these courses were given lab tours and opportunities to do their final course projects using facilities and techniques that were developed in the research. In addition, the research advances generated through this project were presented to high school students via lab tours in Discovery Day and the Center for Diversity in Engineering events. The research activities and findings have been covered by several media as news stories.

 


Last Modified: 08/22/2016
Modified by: Xiaodong Li
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This project aims at synthesizing large quantities of conductive-core/transition-metal-oxide-shell nanocables on a highly flexible and strong carbon microfiber substrate. The primary goal of this work is to solve the three most critical limitations in supercapacitors for portable electronic devices and wearable electronics, i.e., inflexibility, low specific capacitance, and electrode failure resulting from ion insertion/extraction during charge/discharge cycling. The novelty of the approach is the use of electrical conductive-cores to support redox active transition-metal-oxide-shells to achieve highly electrolytic accessible surface area and reliable electrical connections to the shells, enabling full utilization of transitional-metal-oxide and fast electronic and ionic conduction through the electrode. This research program has studied the formation mechanisms of the core/shell nanocables grown on flexible carbon microfibers and the electrochemical energy storage mechanisms of the core/shell – carbon microfiber hybrid composite electrodes. High throughput manufacturing of such composite electrodes with high flexibility, high specific capacitance, high energy density, high power density, fast charging/discharging rate, and long cycle life has been achieved through the novel hierarchical nano/micro architecture design and roll-to-roll processes. Importantly, the flexible supercapacitors have been successfully assembled with flexible solar cells to realize self-sustaining power packs. The results of this research have contributed to a better understanding of the manufacturing-structure-property-function of the core/shell – carbon microfiber hybrid composites and their electrodes. This research has changed the conventional concepts for flexible electrode design and significantly impacted the electrode manufacturing technologies. This project has enhanced the expertise of faculty in this area, helped recruit qualified students, developed new educational opportunities, and increased the public awareness of NSF- driven research and educational activities in NanoManufacturing. Through this project, the principal investigator and students have established collaboration opportunities with 4 universities and 1 national laboratory. This project supported 5 students (1 female student), resulted in 14 scientific papers in prestigious peer reviewed journals, 2 keynotes, 16 invited talks and 4 presentations at international conferences/workshops, and 1 US patent. The research activities were used as an educational platform for students at all levels to learn about NanoManufacturing. The research advances made through this project have generated new knowledge that has been introduced to undergraduate and graduate students through existing courses and newly developed courses (for instance, "Manufacturing Processes", "Manufacturing and Process Technology", "Micro/Nano Manufacturing", "Nanomaterials", and "Nano in a Global Context" offered/co-offered by the principal investigator). Students in these courses were given lab tours and opportunities to do their final course projects using facilities and techniques that were developed in the research. In addition, the research advances generated through this project were presented to high school students via lab tours in Discovery Day and the Center for Diversity in Engineering events.
